doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF THIS IS THE BASIC NASA RESEARCH ANNOUNCEMENT AWARD FOR BOSTON MICROMACHINES. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL ADVANCE THE TECHNOLOGY READINESS OF THE MEMS DMS COMPONENTS THAT ARE CURRENTLY AT THE FOREFRONT OF THE FIELD, AND THE PROJECT WILL BE LED BY THE MANUFACTURER OF THOSE COMPONENTS, BOSTON MICROMACHINES CORPORATION (BMC). THE PROJECT AIMS TO DEMONSTRATE BASIC FUNCTIONALITY AND PERFORMANCE OF THIS COMPONENT IN CRITICAL TEST ENVIRONMENTS WHILE ESTABLISHING MODEL-BASED PREDICTIONS OF ITS PERFORMANCE RELATIVE TO LAUNCH AND SPACE ENVIRONMENTS. BMC MEMS DMS HAVE BEEN PROPOSED IN NASA SPACE-BASED EXOPLANET MISSION CONCEPTS INCLUDING EXTRASOLAR PLANETARY IMAGING CORONAGRAPH (EPIC), EXOPLANETARY CIRCUMSTELLAR ENVIRONMENT AND DISK EXPLORER (EXCEDE), WIDE FIELD CORONAGRAPH SPACE TELESCOPE (WFCST) AND PUPIL-MAPPING EXOPLANET CONONAGRAPHIC OBSERVER (PECO), AMONG OTHERS. BMC IS ONE OF TWO MANUFACTURERS THAT HAVE FIELDED PROTOTYPE MEMS DMS FOR THIS APPLICATION IN NASA TEST BEDS. PRESENTLY BMC IS THE ONLY MEMS DM TECHNOLOGY WORLDWIDE THAT HAS YIELDED FULLY FUNCTIONAL DM COMPONENTS WITH MORE THAN 1000 DEGREES OF FREEDOM. BMC HIGH-ACTUATOR-COUNT MEMS DM COMPONENTS HAVE BEEN INTEGRATED IN EXOPLANET EXPLORATION TEST BEDS USING MULTIMIRROR ARRAY (MMA) ARCHITECTURES WITH 331 INDEPENDENT HEXAGONAL MIRROR SEGMENTS SUPPORTED BY THREE UNDERLYING ELECTROSTATIC ACTUATORS PER SEGMENT, AND USING CONTINUOUS DEFORMABLE MIRROR (CDM) ARCHITECTURES WITH COMPLIANT MIRRORS SUPPORTED BY 1020 UNDERLYING ELECTROSTATIC ACTUATORS. DESPITE BROAD NASA INTEREST IN THE TECHNOLOGY AND STEADY TECHNICAL PROGRESS IN DM DEVELOPMENT AND USE, BMC MEMS COMPONENTS HAVE NOT BEEN TESTED FOR THEIR SURVIVABILITY UPON EXPOSURE TO MECHANICAL SHOCK AND VIBRATION AT LEVELS CONSISTENT WITH SPACE LAUNCH. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO ACHIEVE TWO INTERRELATED TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES THAT DEMONSTRATE THE CAPACITY OF THE MEMS DMS TO SURVIVE DYNAMIC MECHANICAL ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSES ASSOCIATED WITH LAUNCH AND DEPLOYMENT IN SPACE. WITHOUT SUCH TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT, A CORONAGRAPH MISSION USING MEMS DMS WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE.

THE INCREASINGLY RAPID GROWTH OF SENSING, NAVIGATION, COMMUNICATION, HARDWARE, AND SOFTWARE TECHNOLOGIES HAS SPURRED AN INCREASE IN THE DECISION-MAKING AND DECISION-SUPPORT CAPABILITIES OF MODERN INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEMS. THE AIR TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM INVOLVES INTERACTIONS AMONG MULTIPLE DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING THE AIRLINES, AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS, AIRPORT OPERATORS, TRAFFIC MANAGERS, CREW MEMBERS, GROUND HANDLERS AND PASSENGERS, TO NAME JUST A FEW. EACH OF THESE STAKEHOLDERS HAS THEIR OWN OBJECTIVES AND OPERATIONAL CONSTRAINTS, AND MAY OR MAY NOT COOPERATE OR COORDINATE WITH EACH OTHER, DEPENDING ON THE SITUATION. WHILE ADVANCED CONTROL AND OPTIMIZATION ALGORITHMS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE, PRACTICAL CHALLENGES REMAIN DUE TO THE LARGE SCALE AND COMPLEX NATURE OF OPERATIONS, MANY SOURCES OF UNCERTAINTIES, AND COMPETITION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS. THE INTRODUCTION OF UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS IN THE NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM WILL RESULT IN EVEN MORE DIVERSE LEVELS OF ONBOARD AUTONOMY, AND A NEW STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITY. THE EFFICIENT INTEGRATION OF UAS INTO THE NAS REQUIRES AIR TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS THAT ARE ABLE TO DISTRIBUTE RESPONSIBILITIES, WHILE STILL ENSURING SAFETY AND MAXIMIZING EFFICIENCY, UNDER BOTH NOMINAL AND OFF NOMINAL CIRCUMSTANCES. THE PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES IN SENSING, COMMUNICATIONS AND COMPUTATION CAN HELP OVERCOME THESE CHALLENGES BY ENABLING DISTRIBUTED DECISION-MAKING BY STAKEHOLDERS, AND BY PROVIDING BETTER DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS TO SYSTEM OPERATORS. THE OVERARCHING PHILOSOPHY DRIVING THE RESEARCH PROPOSED IN THE AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY ENHANCED AIR TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT PROJECT IS THAT, BY APPROPRIATELY LEVERAGING AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY, THE ATM SYSTEM CAN: BETTER UTILIZE AVAILABLE CAPACITY, AND INCREASE THE AVAILABLE CAPACITY, ESPECIALLY DURING MARGINAL METEOROLOGICAL CONDITIONS, AT CRITICALLY CONGESTED AIRPORTS AND TERMINALAREAS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED WORK ARE TO: IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO ENHANCE AIR TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT SYSTEM PERFORMANCE BY LEVERAGING TECHNIQUES FOR AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY. CONDUCT A GAP ANALYSIS OF TECHNOLOGY AND RESEARCH NEEDS. CONDUCT A RISK-BENEFIT ANALYSIS FOR THE INCREASED USE OF AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY IN NAS OPERATIONS. DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE PROTOTYPE ALGORITHMS FOR TRAFFIC FLOW MANAGEMENT AND CLOSELY SPACED RUNWAY OPERATIONS IN THE PRESENCE OF UNCERTAINTIES, TO HELP ACHIEVE THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF INCREASED AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY. LAYOUT A RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY ROADMAP TO ACHIEVE AUTONOMY AND AUTONOMICITY ENHANCED AIR TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT. THE ABOVE OBJECTIVES WILL BE TACKLED IN THE CONTEXT OF BOTH SYSTEM-WIDE AND FACILITY SPECIFIC OPERATIONS, AND A RANGE OF TIME-SCALES.

SMASS: FOR MORE THAN A DECADE, THE SMALL MAIN-BELT ASTEROID SPECTROSCOPIC SURVEY (SMASS) HAS EXPLORED THE SPECTRAL PROPERTIES OF THE ASTEROID BELT. RECENTLY, SMASS HAS FOCUSED ON THE PROPERTIES OF NEAR-EARTH OBJECTS (NEOS) WHILE KEEPING THE SMASS ACRONYM. CURRENTLY SMASS IS PERFORMING NEAR-INFRARED SPECTRAL MEASUREMENTS WITH "SPEX" ON THE NASA IRTF 3M TELESCOPE. WE HAVE PUBLICLY RELEASED SPECTRA FOR>150 NEOS (-1 KM) HTTP://SMASS.MIT.EDULAND HAVE (WITHIN PAST 3 YEARS)>15 REFEREED PUBLICATIONS AND 2 STUDENT THESES. (LONGER TERM SMASS TOTALS:>50 REFEREED PUBLICATIONS; 6 THESES.] MOST RECENT SCIENTIFIC HIGHLIGHTS INCLUDE: PINPOINTING (COMPOSITIONALLY) THE INNER ASTEROID BELT AS A LIKELY SOURCE FOR THE LARGEST NEOS; METEORITES APPEAR TO BE MUCH MORE BROADLY DERIVED [VERNAZZA, BINZEL ET AL. NATURE 454, 858, 2008]. *CONSTRAINING THE SPACE WEATHERING PROCESS [VERNAZZA, BINZEL ET AL. NATURE 458, 993, 2009]. DETERMINING THAT POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS OBJECT 99942 APOPHIS IS COMPOSITIONALLY MOST ANALOGOUS TO LL CHONDRITE METEORITES (BINZEL ET AL. ICARUS 200, 480, 20091. EXTENDING ASTEROID TAXONOMY INTO THE NEAR-INFRARED; RELEASING A PUBLIC WEB TOOL FOR ASTEROID CLASSIFICATION (DEMEO, BINZEL ET AL. ICARUS, IN PRESS; HTTP://SMASS.MIT.EDULBUSDEMEOCLASS.HTML). SMASS-NEXT: SMASS IS POISED AND READY FOR THE NEXT GENERATION: A NEW STATE-OF-THE-ART "SPEX-LIKE" INSTRUMENT (CALLED "FIRE"; FUNDED BY THE NSF/MRI PROGRAM) IS COMING ONLINE (MID-2009) FOR THE MAGELLAN 6.5M TELESCOPE. "SMASS-NEXTLT WILL USE MAGELLAN+FIRE TO PUSH SPECTROSCOPY TO THE FAINTEST LIMITS (V>19.0) YET ACHIEVED IN NEO CHARACTERIZATION SURVEYS. RAPID PUBLIC RELEASE OF DATA WILL CONTINUE IN THE SMASS-NEXT PROGRAM. SCIENCE OBJECTIVES: OUR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE DEFINED BY QUESTIONS AT THE FRONTIER OF CURRENT KNOWLEDGE OF THE NEO POPULATION, THEREBY OF INTRINSIC IMPORTANCE WITHIN PLANETARY SCIENCE: (I) HOW DOES THE COMPOSITIONAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE NEO POPULATION VARY WITH SIZE? (II) HOW WELL DO NEOS DIRECTLY COMPARE WITH THE POPULATION THAT APPEARS TO BE THEIR PREDOMINANT SOURCE; -1 KM ASTEROIDS IN THE INNER MAIN-BELT? (ILL) WHICH NEOS PROVIDE THE MOST SCIENTIFICALLY IMPORTANT DESTINATIONS FOR FUTURE EXPLORATION? (IV) WHAT IS THE NATURE OF THE POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS OBJECT (PHO) POPULATION? MERIT AND IMPACT: THE MERIT AND IMPACT OF OUR OBJECTIVES WILL BE TO UNRAVEL OBSERVATIONALLY, AND THEREBY TEST DIRECTLY, DELIVERY PROCESSES AND SOURCES FOR NEOS AND METEORITES. WE WILL ADDITIONALLY ADDRESS DIRECTLY THE POPULATION AND SOURCE OF PHOS. OUR RESULTS WILL IMPACT OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE YARKOVSKY EFFECT", THE ROLE AND OUTCOMES OF ASTEROID COLLISIONS, AND THE DYNAMICS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF DELIVERY RESONANCES. OUR FINDINGS WILL TIE DIRECTLY TO STUDIES OF METEORITES AND THEIR LINKS TO PLANETARY FORMATION. FURTHER, WE WILL BE A PATHFINDER FOR FUTURE NEO MISSIONS FOR SAMPLE RETURN, HAZARDOUS OBJECT ASSESSMENT~ RESOURCE UTILIZATION, AND POSSIBLE HUMAN EXPLORATION. NEOO PROGRAMMATIC CAPABILITIES: WE PROPOSE TO ADD A SUBSTANTIAL NEW LARGE APERTURE ASSET (MAGELLAN 6.5M, LAS CAMPANAS, CHILE). IN THE SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE, FOR NEO CHARACTERIZATION. WE WILL INCREASE BY A FACTOR OF2X TO 3X NASA'S CURRENT SPECTROSCOPIC CHARACTERIZATION CAPABILITY FOR>I KM NEOS, FOR>140 M PHOS, AND FOR HIGHLY ACCESSIBLE SPACECRAFT DESTINATIONS. WE WILL CONTINUE UTILIZATION OF THE NASA IRTF FOR OBSERVABLE (V<17.5) NORTHERN HEMISPHERE TARGETS. OUR NEAR-IR SPECTRAL MEASUREMENTS WILL COMPLEMENT THE FAR-INFRARED WAVELENGTH RANGE OF THE WISE MISSION AND THE VISIBLE COLORS OF PAN-ST ARRS. CONCLUDING REMARKS: FUNDING OR REJECTION OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL DETERMINE THE CONTINUATION OR THE END OF THE MIT SMASS PROGRAM, ARGUABLY FULL TIME POSTDOCTORAL ASSOCIATE (PERSON TBD), ONE GRADUATE STUDENT, AND DATA ACQUISITION

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF THE PROPOSED INNOVATION IS A POWER CONVERSION TECHNOLOGY THAT WILL HELP ACHIEVE NASA'S FUNDAMENTAL AERONAUTICS PROGRAM (FAP) GOALS OF REDUCING EMISSIONS AND INCREASING FUEL EFFICIENCY FOR HIGH SPEED FLIGHT. NASA'S OBJECTIVE TO INCREASE THE SPECIFIC POWER OF HIGH EFFICIENCY ELECTRIC COMPONENTS IN ORDER TO MAKE A 10 MEGA-WATT ONBOARD POWER GENERATION AND/OR UTILIZATION FEASIBLE FOR PROPULSION REQUIRES THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUB-SCALE TECHNOLOGIES TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF NEWER TURBOELECTRIC AIRCRAFT AND EMBEDDED BOUNDARY LAYER ELECTRIC PROPULSION SYSTEMS. COMPACT AND LIGHTWEIGHT TURBINE GENERATORS SCALING FROM THE KW TO MW CLASS ARE NEEDED TO TRANSITION HIGH SPEED AIRCRAFT TO HYBRID ELECTRIC PROPULSION SYSTEMS. METIS DESIGN CORP IS DEVELOPING A LIGHTWEIGHT, COMPACT, GAS TURBINE GENERATOR THAT DRAWS ON RECENT INNOVATIONS IN THE FIELDS OF PERMANENT MAGNET GENERATORS AND TURBOMACHINERY, TO ACHIEVE A TARGET POWER DENSITY OF OVER TWICE THE STATE-OF-THE-ART AND THE POTENTIAL TO SCALE TO 100'S OF KW. THE PROPOSED TURBINE ENGINE USES A LIGHTWEIGHT, TWO-SPOOL CONFIGURATION THAT ELIMINATES THE NEED FOR THE HEAVY REDUCTION GEARBOX REQUIRED BY STATE-OF-THE-ART SYSTEMS. PHASE II OF THIS SBIR EFFORT WILL DEVELOP A DETAILED DESIGN, THEN FABRICATE AND TEST THE COMPLETE TURBINE GENERATO SUB-SYSTEM IN A LABORATORY ENVIRONMENT.
